16.text: About four years ago, the New Yorker published an article

19.text: about a cache of dodo bones that was found

21.text: in a pit on the island of Mauritius.

24.text: Now, the island of Mauritius is a small island

26.text: off the east coast of Madagascar

29.text: in the Indian Ocean, and it is the place

31.text: where the dodo bird was discovered

34.text: and extinguished, all within about 150 years.

37.text: Everyone was very excited about this archaeological find,

40.text: because it meant that they might finally be able

42.text: to assemble a single dodo skeleton.

44.text: See, while museums all over the world

46.text: have dodo skeletons in their collection, nobody --

49.text: not even the actual Natural History Museum

51.text: on the island of Mauritius -- has a skeleton that's made

53.text: from the bones of a single dodo.

58.text: The fact is, is that the British Museum

60.text: had a complete specimen of a dodo in their collection

64.text: it was actually mummified, skin and all --

66.text: but in a fit of space-saving zeal,

68.text: they actually cut off the head and they cut off the feet

70.text: and they burned the rest in a bonfire.

73.text: If you go look at their website today,

75.text: they'll actually list these specimens, saying,

77.text: the rest was lost in a fire.

80.text: Not quite the whole truth. Anyway.

83.text: The frontispiece of this article was this photo,

85.text: and I'm one of the people that thinks that Tina Brown

87.text: was great for bringing photos to the New Yorker,

89.text: because this photo completely rocked my world.

91.text: I became obsessed with the object --

93.text: not just the beautiful photograph itself,

95.text: and the color, the shallow depth of field, the detail that's visible,

98.text: the wire you can see on the beak there

100.text: that the conservator used to put this skeleton together --

109.text: if I had my own dodo skeleton?

115.text: I want to point out here at this point that

120.text: by objects and the stories that they tell,

123.text: and this was the very latest one.

125.text: So I began looking around for --

127.text: to see if anyone sold a kit,

129.text: some kind of model that I could get,

131.text: and I found lots of reference material, lots of lovely pictures.

134.text: No dice: no dodo skeleton for me. But the damage had been done.

138.text: I had saved a few hundred photos of dodo skeletons

142.text: it's a repository for my brain, everything that I could possibly be interested in.

145.text: Any time I have an internet connection,

147.text: there's a sluice of stuff moving into there,

150.text: everything from beautiful rings to cockpit photos.

154.text: The key that the Marquis du Lafayette sent to George Washington

157.text: to celebrate the storming of the Bastille.

165.text: because I couldn't afford the one on eBay.

167.text: Storm trooper costumes. Maps of Middle Earth --

170.text: that's one I hand-drew myself. There's the dodo skeleton folder.

178.text: And one day, a couple of weeks later, it might have been

181.text: maybe a year later, I was in the art store with my kids,

183.text: and I was buying some clay tools -- we were going to have a craft day.

186.text: I bought some Super Sculpeys, some armature wire, some various materials.

189.text: And I looked down at this Sculpey, and I thought,

193.text: yeah, maybe I could make my own dodo skull.

197.text: I should point out at this time -- I'm not a sculptor;

201.text: You give me a drawing, you give me a prop to replicate,

204.text: you give me a crane, scaffolding, parts from "Star Wars" --

209.text: I can do this stuff all day long.

211.text: It's exactly how I made my living for 15 years.

213.text: But you give me something like this --

216.text: my friend Mike Murnane sculpted this;

218.text: it's a maquette for "Star Wars, Episode Two" --

222.text: this is something other people do -- dragons, soft things.

225.text: However, I felt like I had looked at enough photos of dodo skulls

231.text: understand the topology and perhaps replicate it --

234.text: I mean, it couldn't be that difficult.

236.text: So, I started looking at the best photos I could find.

241.text: and I found this lovely piece of reference.

243.text: This is someone selling this on eBay;

245.text: it was clearly a woman’s hand, hopefully a woman's hand.

248.text: Assuming it was roughly the size of my wife's hand,

250.text: I made some measurements of her thumb, and I scaled them out to the size of the skull.

253.text: I blew it up to the actual size, and I began using that,

256.text: along with all the other reference that I had, comparing it to it

258.text: as size reference for figuring out exactly how big the beak should be,

263.text: And over a few hours, I eventually achieved

266.text: what was actually a pretty reasonable dodo skull. And I didn't mean to continue, I --

269.text: it's kind of like, you know, you can only clean a super messy room

272.text: by picking up one thing at a time; you can't think about the totality.

275.text: I wasn't thinking about a dodo skeleton;

277.text: I just noticed that as I finished this skull,

279.text: the armature wire that I had been used to holding it up

281.text: was sticking out of the back just where a spine would be.

283.text: And one of the other things I'd been interested in and obsessed with over the years

286.text: is spines and skeletons, having collected a couple of hundred.

291.text: of vertebrae enough to kind of start to imitate them.

296.text: vertebrae by vertebrae, I built my way down.

299.text: And actually, by the end of the day, I had a reasonable skull,

302.text: a moderately good vertebrae and half of a pelvis.

306.text: And again, I kept on going, looking for more reference,

309.text: every bit of reference I could find -- drawings, beautiful photos.

312.text: This guy -- I love this guy! He put a dodo leg bones on a scanner

317.text: This is the kind of accuracy that I wanted,

321.text: replicated every last bone and put it in.

334.text: You can see that I even made a museum label for it

336.text: that includes a brief history of the dodo.

338.text: And TAP Plastics made me -- although I didn't photograph it --

342.text: I don't have the room for this in my house,

344.text: but I had to finish what I had started.

347.text: And this actually represented kind of a sea change to me.

350.text: Again, like I said, my life has been about

352.text: being fascinated by objects and the stories that they tell,

354.text: and also making them for myself, obtaining them,

357.text: appreciating them and diving into them.

362.text: there are tons of projects that I'm currently working on,

365.text: projects that I've already worked on, things that I might want to work on some day,

368.text: and things that I may just want to find and buy and have

373.text: But now there was potentially this new category of things

378.text: that was different, that I -- you know,

380.text: I have my own R2D2, but that's --

382.text: honestly, relative to sculpting, to me, that's easy.

385.text: And so I went back and looked through my "Creative Projects" folder,

388.text: and I happened across the Maltese Falcon.

392.text: Now, this is funny for me:

395.text: to fall in love with an object from a Hammett novel,

398.text: because if it's true that the world is divided into two types of people,

400.text: Chandler people and Hammett people, I am absolutely a Chandler person.

405.text: it's not about the author, it's not about the book or the movie or the story,

409.text: it's about the object in and of itself.

411.text: And in this case, this object is --

414.text: plays on a host of levels.

417.text: First of all, there's the object in the world.

421.text: It is a ceremonial pouring vessel

423.text: made around 1700 for a Swedish Count,

427.text: and it is very likely the object from which

429.text: Hammett drew his inspiration for the Maltese Falcon.

432.text: Then there is the fictional bird, the one that Hammett created for the book.

435.text: Built out of words, it is the engine

437.text: that drives the plot of his book and also the movie,

440.text: in which another object is created:

442.text: a prop that has to represent the thing that Hammett created out of words,

445.text: inspired by the Kniphausen Hawk, and this represents the falcon in the movie.

449.text: And then there is this fourth level, which is

451.text: a whole new object in the world:

453.text: the prop made for the movie, the representative of the thing,

460.text: a whole new object of desire.

462.text: And so now it was time to do some research.

464.text: I actually had done some research

466.text: a few years before -- it's why the folder was there.

468.text: I'd bought a replica, a really crappy replica,

470.text: of the Maltese Falcon on eBay,

472.text: and had downloaded enough pictures to actually

483.text: one of the original lead birds

485.text: had been sold at Christie's in 1994,

487.text: and so I contacted an antiquarian bookseller

490.text: who had the original Christie's catalogue,

492.text: and in it I found this magnificent picture,

496.text: I was able to scan the picture, blow it up to exactly full size.

500.text: I found other reference. Avi [Ara] Chekmayan,

502.text: a New Jersey editor, actually found this

509.text: although it took him five years

515.text: because there was a lot of controversy about it.

517.text: It was made out of resin, which wasn't a common material for movie props

519.text: about the time the movie was made.

521.text: It's funny to me that it took a while to authenticate it,

523.text: because I can see it compared to this thing,

525.text: and I can tell you -- it's real, it's the real thing,

527.text: it's made from the exact same mold that this one is.

530.text: In this one, because the auction was actually so controversial,

533.text: Profiles in History, the auction house that sold this --

535.text: I think in 1995 for about 100,000 dollars --

537.text: they actually included -- you can see here on the bottom --

540.text: not just a front elevation, but also

546.text: So now, I had all the topology I needed

551.text: What do they do, how do you start something like that? I really don't know.

554.text: So what I did was, again, like I did with the dodo skull,

556.text: I blew all my reference up to full size,

559.text: and then I began cutting out the negatives and using

563.text: So I took Sculpey, and I built a big block of it,

565.text: and I passed it through until, you know, I got the right profiles.

568.text: And then slowly, feather by feather, detail by detail,

573.text: working in front of the television and Super Sculpey --

575.text: here's me sitting next to my wife --

577.text: it's the only picture I took of the entire process.

580.text: As I moved through, I achieved

582.text: a very reasonable facsimile of the Maltese Falcon.

584.text: But again, I am not a sculptor,

586.text: and so I don't know a lot of the tricks, like,

589.text: I don't know how my friend Mike gets beautiful, shiny surfaces with his Sculpey;

592.text: I certainly wasn't able to get it.

594.text: So, I went down to my shop,

596.text: and I molded it and I cast it in resin,

599.text: because in the resin, then, I could absolutely get the glass smooth finished.

602.text: Now there's a lot of ways to fill and get yourself a nice smooth finish.

605.text: My preference is about 70 coats of this --

610.text: I spray it on for about three or four days, it drips to hell,

613.text: but it allows me a really, really nice gentle sanding surface

616.text: and I can get it glass-smooth.

618.text: Oh, finishing up with triple-zero steel wool.

620.text: Now, the great thing about getting it to this point was that

623.text: because in the movie, when they finally bring out the bird at the end,

625.text: and they place it on the table, they actually spin it.

628.text: So I was able to actually

630.text: screen-shot and freeze-frame to make sure.

633.text: And I'm following all the light kicks on this thing and making sure that as I'm holding the light

636.text: in the same position, I'm getting the same type of reflection on it --

639.text: that's the level of detail I'm going into this thing.

642.text: I ended up with this: my Maltese Falcon.

645.text: And it's beautiful. And I can state with authority

647.text: at this point in time, when I'd finished it,

649.text: of all of the replicas out there -- and there is a few --

652.text: this is by far the most accurate

654.text: representation of the original Maltese Falcon

656.text: than anyone has sculpted. Now the original one, I should tell you,

659.text: is sculpted by a guy named Fred Sexton.

661.text: This is where it gets weird.

664.text: Fred Sexton was a friend of this guy, George Hodel.

667.text: Terrifying guy -- agreed by many to be the killer

673.text: that Fred Sexton, the sculptor of the Maltese Falcon,

678.text: I'll go you one stranger than that: In 1974,

681.text: during the production of a weird comedy sequel to "The Maltese Falcon,"

684.text: called "The Black Bird," starring George Segal,

686.text: the Los Angeles County Museum of Art

688.text: had a plaster original of the Maltese Falcon --

690.text: one of the original six plasters, I think, made for the movie --

693.text: stolen out of the museum. A lot of people thought

695.text: it was a publicity stunt for the movie.

699.text: is seen briefly in "The Maltese Falcon,"

701.text: is still a viable San Francisco eatery,

703.text: counted amongst its regular customers Elisha Cook,

705.text: who played Wilmer Cook in the movie,

709.text: one of his original plasters of the Maltese Falcon.

712.text: And they had it in their cabinet for about 15 years,

720.text: It would seem that the object of desire

722.text: only comes into its own by disappearing repeatedly.

725.text: So here I had this Falcon,

727.text: and it was lovely. It looked really great,

729.text: the light worked on it really well,

731.text: it was better than anything that I could achieve

733.text: or obtain out in the world.

735.text: But there was a problem. And the problem was that:

739.text: I wanted the entirety of the object,

741.text: I wanted the weight behind the object.

744.text: This thing was made of resin and it was too light.

746.text: There's this group online that I frequent.

748.text: It's a group of prop crazies just like me

751.text: called the Replica Props Forum, and it's people who trade,

753.text: make and travel in information about movie props.

756.text: And it turned out that one of the guys there,

758.text: a friend of mine that I never actually met,

761.text: but befriended through some prop deals, was the manager of a local foundry.

825.text: Now, here's the most recent progression of Falcons.

828.text: On the far left is a piece of crap -- a replica I bought on eBay.

831.text: There's my somewhat ruined Sculpey Falcon,

833.text: because I had to get it back out of the mold. There's my first casting,

836.text: there's my master and there's my bronze.

838.text: There's a thing that happens when you mold and cast things,

841.text: which is that every time you throw it into silicone and cast it in resin,

843.text: you lose a little bit of volume, you lose a little bit of size.

846.text: And when I held my bronze one up against my Sculpey one,

849.text: it was shorter by three-quarters of an inch.

852.text: Yeah, no, really, this was like aah --

858.text: Why didn't I start and make it bigger?

861.text: So what do I do? I figure I have two options.

864.text: One, I can fire a freaking laser at it,

869.text: to do a 3D scan -- there's a 3D scan of this Falcon.

871.text: I had figured out the exact amount of shrinkage I achieved

874.text: going from a wax master to a bronze master

876.text: and blown this up big enough to make

880.text: which I will polish, then I will send to the mold maker

883.text: and then I will have it done in bronze. Or:

886.text: There are several people who own originals,

888.text: and I have been attempting to contact them and reach them,

891.text: hoping that they will let me spend a few minutes

894.text: in the presence of one of the real birds, maybe to take a picture,

896.text: or even to pull out the hand-held laser scanner

899.text: that I happen to own that fits inside a cereal box,

902.text: and could maybe, without even touching their bird, I swear,

904.text: get a perfect 3D scan. And I'm even willing to sign pages

907.text: saying that I'll never let anyone else have it, except for me in my office, I promise.

910.text: I'll give them one if they want it.

913.text: And then, maybe, then I'll achieve the end of this exercise.

916.text: But really, if we're all going to be honest with ourselves,

918.text: I have to admit that achieving the end of the exercise

921.text: was never the point of the exercise to begin with, was it.
